Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Aquisition of a Time-Resolved Confocal Microscope for Research and Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) programs, the University of Montana will acquire a time-resolved confocal microscope. The instrument consists of a pulsed laser light source and a microscope. The microscope detects the light that is emitted (fluorescence) from a sample after irradiation by the light source. The instrument facilitates investigation of cellular complexes down to single-molecules using time-resolved fluorescence techniques. It will be used in the investigation of molecular and biomolecular interactions and mechanisms in the chemical, biochemical and biological sciences. The instrument will be used by undergraduate and graduate students in their research. This training will assist them in future careers as fluorescence microscopy techniques are widely used in the biotechnology and materials industry. The acquisition will be used in outreach activities including programs to recruit Native American students.

The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) studying immobilized bifunctional catalysts, photocatalysts and metal sensors; (b) studying binding and dynamics of cytochrome c on cardiolipin nanodiscs; (c) investigating biogenic amines, the extracellular matrix, and neuronal development; (d) investigating the mechanisms for dynamic localization of stem cell regulator FBF-2 in C. elegans; and (e) studying the mechanism and dynamics of G-protein activation by Ric-8A.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The BioSpectroscopy Core Research Laboratory (BCRL) at the University of Montana is an established multi-user facility that provides time-resolved fluorescence microscopy and spectroscopy tools for education and research at the University and other academic and research institutions in the Pacific Northwest. The funded Major Research Instrumentation proposal enabled the BCRL to purchase a time-resolved confocal fluorescence microscope system, the PicoQuant MicroTime 200. This is a state-of-the-art, high-end instrument that meets critical needs of established, funded research programs at the University of Montana that are investigating the interactions, dynamics and mechanisms of biomolecules and nanomaterials in model systems and cells.

The PicoQuant MicroTime 200 replaced an outdated, home-built instrument and is providing meaningful research experiences in materials science, chemistry, biochemistry, and biophysics to undergraduate and graduate students. Educational use of equipment in the BCRL takes two distinct forms: (1) in-depth instruction for students using the equipment independently for research; and (2) support for courses offered as part of the undergraduate and graduate degree programs in Chemistry, Biochemistry & Biophysics, and Materials Science.

Availability of the PicoQuant MicroTime 200 for education and research to the wider Montana and Pacific Northwest communities has been communicated in classroom lectures of the Montana University System Materials Science Program and through public lectures at Montana Tech, Butte, and the University of Montana, Missoula, as well as through the BCRL web page (http://hs.umt.edu/cbsd/facilities/biospectroscopy/default.php). It is also an essential research and teaching component of a new international collaboration between the University of Montana (USA), the University of Lethbridge (Canada), and the University of Canterbury (New Zealand).
